bibl.title: Letter from Alberto Recio Forns to Philip Showalter Hench, June 7, 1940

div1.p: Forns discusses the identification of Camp Lazear from photographs taken by Alvare.

div1.head: Letter from Alberto Recio Forns to Philip Showalter Hench, June 7, 1940
div1.opener:
LABORATORIO CLINICO
DEL
DR. ALBERTO RECIO
AVE. DE LA INDEPENDENCIA Y MONTORO
TELEFONO U-2659
H A B A N A
----
June 7, 1940
Received: June 13, 1940.
Dr. P. S. Hench
102-110 Second Ave. S.W.
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I am sorry to have delayed so much answering your let-
ter of April 30 but I have just come back from Washington
where I attended the Pan American Scientific meeting.

Referring to the photograph of the supposed remainings
of Camp Lazear, I may inform as follows:

In 1926 when Dr. Ignacio Alvaré was intern at the Col-
umbia Military Hospital which is located near the site where
the photograph was taken, he was told by the neighbors that
the small house was what remained of Camp Lazear. As he knew
the interest I had for everything related to the 1900 yellow
fever experiments he took a picture of the small building
and gave me a copy. A few days later I showed it to Dr. Arís-
tides Agramonte who said: “I would not recognize it, were
it not for the tree”, without any other explanation.

Dr. Alvaré further tells me that the 1926 hurricane
tore the house down, that is shortly after the picture was
taken.

Dr. Ignacio Alvaré's address is: Calle 9, 304
(Vedado), Havana, and I am certain he will be glad to let
you know all he knows in connection with this matter.
